{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Jorge Burruchaga | image = Burruchaga gritando gol de argentina.JPG | image_size = 250 | alt = | caption = Burruchaga celebrating after scoring the 3rd goal vs. [[Germany national football team|West Germany]] at the [[1986 FIFA World Cup]] final. | fullname = Jorge Luis Burruchaga | height = {{height|m=1.77}}{{NFT player|id=14893|accessdate=11 June 2015}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1962|10|9}} | birth_place = [[Gualeguay, Entre Ríos|Gualeguay]], Argentina | position = [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|Attacking Midfielder]]
[[Forward (association football)#Second striker|Second striker]] | currentclub = | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Arsenal de Sarandí]] | years1 = 1979–1981 | clubs1 = [[Arsenal de Sarandí]] | caps1 = 49 | goals1 = 7 | years2 = 1981–1985 | clubs2 = [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]] | caps2 = 146 | goals2 = 53 | years3 = 1985–1992 | clubs3 = [[FC Nantes Atlantique|Nantes]] | caps3 = 140 | goals3 = 27 | years4 = 1992–1993 | clubs4 = [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]] | caps4 = 32 | goals4 = 10 | years5 = 1995–1998 | clubs5 = [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]] | caps5 = 89 | goals5 = 19 | totalcaps = 456 | totalgoals = 116 | nationalyears1 = 1981 | nationalteam1 = [[Argentina national under-20 football team|Argentina U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 1983–1990 | nationalteam2 = [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] | nationalcaps2 = 57 | nationalgoals2 = 13 | manageryears1 = 2002–2005 | managerclubs1 = [[Arsenal de Sarandí]] | manageryears2 = 2005–2006 | managerclubs2 = [[Estudiantes de La Plata|Estudiantes]] | manageryears3 = 2006–2007 | managerclubs3 = [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]] | manageryears4 = 2008–2009 | managerclubs4 = [[Club Atlético Banfield|Banfield]] | manageryears5 = 2009–2010 | managerclubs5 = [[Arsenal de Sarandí]] | manageryears6 = 2011–2012 | managerclubs6 = [[Club Libertad|Libertad]] | manageryears7 = 2012–2014 | managerclubs7 = [[Atlético de Rafaela]] | manageryears8 = 2015–2016 | managerclubs8 = [[Atlético de Rafaela]] }} '''Jorge Luis Burruchaga''' ({{IPA-es|ˈxoɾxe βuruˈtʃaɣa}}; nicknamed ''Burru'', born 9 October 1962) is an [[Argentines|Argentine]] [[association football]] coach and former professional football player, born in [[Gualeguay, Entre Ríos|Gualeguay]], [[Entre Ríos Province|Entre Ríos]]. He played both as an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]] and [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]], scored the winning goal in the final of the [[1986 FIFA World Cup]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/26444580 |title=World Cup 2014: 100 great World Cup moments – 41 days to go |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 May 2014 |accessdate=24 June 2014 }} ==Club career== Burruchaga started playing in [[Primera B Metropolitana#List of champions|1980]] for [[Arsenal de Sarandí]] in [[Primera B Metropolitana|Argentina's then second division]]. He was bought by [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]] in [[1982 Argentine Primera División|1982]] and debuted in a victory against [[Estudiantes de La Plata]] on 12 February. He was part of the team that won the [[1983 Argentine Primera División#Metropolitano Championship)|Metropolitano 1983]], the [[Copa Libertadores 1984|Copa Libertadores]]{{cite web|url=http://www.worldfootball.net/schedule/copa-libertadores-1984-finale/0/ |title=Copa Libertadores 1984 |publisher=World Football |accessdate=24 June 2014 }} and the [[1984 Intercontinental Cup|Intercontinental Cup]] in 1984.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/clubs/matchreport/newsid=512088.html |title=Toyota Cup 1984 |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=24 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080306222947/http://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/clubs/matchreport/newsid%3D512088.html |archivedate= 6 March 2008 |df= }} He was then transferred to French team [[FC Nantes|Nantes]], where he played for seven years. He also played one year for [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]], where he was involved in a bribing scandal involving the French and European champions [[Olympique de Marseille]] 'buying' a 1–0 league win at Valenciennes on 20 May 1993. Marseille midfield player [[Jean-Jacques Eydelie]] and the club's general manager, [[Jean-Pierre Bernes]], had offered him money to throw the game, Burruchaga said he agreed but then changed his mind.{{cite web | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-scandal-leaves-a-stain-on-the-white-shirt-of-marseille-allegations-of-matchfixing-of-francfilled-envelopes-buried-in-gardens-are-threatening-to-dethrone-the-kings-of-french-football-nick-bidwell-reports-1484695.html | title = Football: Scandal leaves a stain on the white shirt of Marseille: Allegations of match-fixing, of franc-filled envelopes buried in gardens are threatening to dethrone the kings of French football. Nick Bidwell reports | website = The Independent | date = 13 July 1993 | accessdate = 11 June 2015 | first = Nick | last = Bidwell}} He was subsequently given a suspended six months sentence when judgment was delivered on 15 May 1995.{{cite web | url = http://www.espnfc.com/story/894439/rewind-to-1993-the-shame-of-marseille | title = The shame of Marseille | website = ESPN FC | date = 10 March 2011 | accessdate = 11 June 2015 | first = Tom | last = Adams}} He returned to [[Argentina]] for his last spell in [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]], when he won a [[1995 Supercopa Libertadores|Supercopa Sudamericana]]{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/sacups/supcopa95full.html |title=Supercopa Libertadores 1995 – Full Details |publisher=RSSSF | date = 11 April 2001 | accessdate = 11 June 2015 | first = Josef | last = Bobrowsky}} and a [[1995 Recopa Sudamericana|Recopa Sudamericana]] both in 1995.{{cite web | url = http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=634523 | title = Un estigma que se reitera | language = es | website = Lá Nación | accessdate = 11 June 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/sacups/recopa94.html |title=Recopa 1994 |publisher=RSSSF | date = 3 July 2003 | accessdate = 11 June 2015 | first = Erik | last = Garin}} He retired from professional football on 10 April 1998 in a match against [[Club Atlético Vélez Sársfield|Vélez Sársfield]]. ==International career== Burruchaga was part of the team that won the [[1986 FIFA World Cup]], scoring two goals, including the goal that gave [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] the 3–2 victory against [[Germany national football team|West Germany]] in [[1986 FIFA World Cup Final|the final match]].{{cite web | url = https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/round=3467/match=393/index.html | title = Argentina 3–2 Germany FR | website = FIFA | accessdate = 11 June 2015}} He also participated in all Argentine matches at the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]] and scored one goal in the tournament. He scored a total of 13 goals for Argentina in 59 games between 1983 and 1990.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/arg-recintlp.html |title=Argentina - Record International Players |website=RSSSF |date=8 January 2015 |accessdate=11 June 2015 |first=Roberto |last=Mamrud |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mr4olopA?url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/arg-recintlp.html |archivedate=17 January 2010 |df= }} ==Managerial career== Burruchaga coached [[Arsenal de Sarandí]] since its arrival to first division in 2002, and succeeded in keeping the team far from the bottom of the standings. For the 2005–06 season, he signed with [[Estudiantes de La Plata]]. In May 2006, he moved to [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]] and resigned on April 2007. He has also managed [[Club Atlético Banfield|Banfield]] from 2008 to 2009 On 5 May 2009, Burruchaga returned to [[Arsenal de Sarandí]] but resigned in 2010. He managed [[Paraguayan Primera División|Paraguayan]] [[Club Libertad]] since 2011. He managed Atletico Rafaela in the Argentinian Primera Division from 2012 to June 2014.{{cite web | url = http://www.ole.com.ar/atletico-rafaela/Entrenador-Crema_0_1145285723.html | title = Entrenador sin Crema | trans-title = Coach without Cream | language = es | website = Olé | date = 26 May 2014 | accessdate = 11 June 2015}} In 2015, Burruchaga returned to Rafaela in his second period as a coach.[http://www.ole.com.ar/atletico-rafaela/Burruchaga-Rafaela_0_1481252057.html] ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! colspan=3 | Club performance ! colspan=2 | League ! colspan=2 | Cup ! colspan=2 | League Cup ! colspan=2 | Continental ! colspan=2 | Total |- ! {{Use Australian English|date=December 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Lead too short|date=February 2010}}
[[File:Australie Aborigene ancetre totemique kangourou.jpg|thumbnail|upright|Kangaroo totemic ancestor - Australian [[Indigenous Australians|Aboriginal]] [[bark painting]], [[Arnhem Land]], c. 1915.]] '''Kangaroo emblems and popular culture''' deals with how the [[kangaroo]] has become a recognisable symbol of [[Australia]], both within Australia itself, and internationally. It also deals with the various uses which have been made of the image and name of the kangaroo.
== European first encounters== The kangaroo was considered a unique oddity when [[James Cook|Captain Cook's]] [[HMS Endeavour|HMB ''Endeavour'']] arrived back in England in 1771 with a specimen on board. Over time it has come to symbolise Australia and Australian values.<ref>Harper, Melissa and White, Richard (eds) (2010). Symbols of Australia, p. 28-29, UNSW Press, Sydney: National Museum of Australia Press, Canberra. {{ISBN|978-1-921410-50-5}}</ref>
[[Joseph Banks]], the naturalist on the ''Endeavour'' voyage, commissioned [[George Stubbs]] to paint a portrait of the kangaroo specimen. When the official account of the voyage was published in 1773, it was illustrated with an engraving of Stubbs' kangaroo. From that time on, the kangaroo quickly came to symbolise the Australian continent, appearing in exhibitions, collections, art and printed works across Europe.<ref name="nmaKangaroo">[http://www.nma.gov.au/exhibitions/symbols_of_australia/kangaroo/ Symbols of Australia: Kangaroo, National Museum of Australia]</ref>
== Kangaroo status == It took a long time for the kangaroo to achieve official recognition in Australia. Despite being a "declared noxious animal" because of its reputation for damaging crops and fences and competing with domestic animals for resources, the kangaroo finally achieved official recognition with its inclusion on [[Australian Coat of Arms|Australia's coat of arms]] in 1908.<ref>Harper, Melissa and White, Richard (eds) (2010). Symbols of Australia, p. 24. UNSW Press, Sydney: National Museum of Australia Press, Canberra. {{ISBN|978-1-921410-50-5}}</ref> The kangaroo is now popularly regarded as Australia’s unofficial animal emblem.<ref>[http://www.dfat.gov.au/facts/national_icons.html Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: About Australia – National Icons] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111019233119/http://dfat.gov.au/facts/national_icons.html |date=19 October 2011 }}</ref>
The [[kangaroo]] has appeared on [[coin]]s and [[emblem]]s, been used in [[logo]]s, [[architecture|architectural decoration]], the [[decorative arts]] and public art, been a [[mascot]] and used in the naming of [[sport]]s teams. Kangaroos also appear in books, television series, films, cartoons, games and songs.
==Kangaroo emblems and logos== [[File:Coat of Arms of Australia.svg|thumb|200px|right|Australian Coat-of-Arms]]
The kangaroo and [[emu]] are bearers on the [[Australian Coat of Arms]]. It has been claimed these animals were chosen to signify a country moving 'forward' because of a common belief that neither can move backward.<ref>Harper, Melissa and White, Richard (eds) (2010). Symbols of Australia, p. 25. UNSW Press, Sydney: National Museum of Australia Press, Canberra. {{ISBN|978-1-921410-50-5}}</ref>
Two red kangaroos serve as bearers to the [[Coat of Arms of Western Australia]].
Australia's national airline, [[Qantas]], uses a bounding kangaroo for its logo. The kangaroo has always been part of the Qantas logo,<ref>[http://www.qantas.com.au/travel/airlines/history-kangaroo-symbol/global/en Qantas: The Kangaroo Symbol]</ref> and the airline has previously been known informally as "The Flying Kangaroo".
[[Tourism Australia]] makes use of the kangaroo in its logo to "help ensure instant recognition for Australia around the world".<ref>[http://www.tourism.australia.com/en-au/brand-australia_5536.aspx Tourism Australia: Using the Brandmark]</ref>
The [[Australian made logo|Australian Grown]] logo uses a golden kangaroo in a green triangle to show that a product is made or grown in Australia.<ref>[http://www.australianmade.com.au/logo/ Australian Made | Australian Grown]</ref>
The [[Royal Australian Air Force]] [[roundel]] features a bounding red kangaroo.
Warships of the [[Royal Australian Navy]] have red kangaroo symbols (based on the kangaroo on the reverse of the [[Penny (Australian)|Australian penny]]) fixed to either side of their superstructure or funnel. This originated during the Korean War: as the destroyer {{HMAS|Anzac|D59|6}} was repeatedly mistaken for a British warship, her executive officer had a brass 'weathervane' in the shape of a kangaroo made and mounted to the ship's mainmast.<ref>{{cite book |last=Cassells |first=Vic |title=The Destroyers: their battles and their badges |year=2000 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=East Roseville, NSW |isbn=0-7318-0893-2 |oclc=46829686 |pages=11–12}}</ref>
The kangaroo is part of the official emblem of the [[Royal Australian Regiment]] with a kangaroo in between two [[Lee–Enfield]] bolt-action rifles.
The [[Coat of arms of Victoria (Australia)|Victorian Coat of Arms]] includes the upper portion of a kangaroo holding an [[Imperial State Crown|Imperial Crown]] in its paws.
The red kangaroo is the animal emblem of the [[Northern Territory]].
The kangaroo is the official emblem of [[Northern Territory Police]].
British clothing and headwear company [[Kangol]], known for its berets, features a kangaroo in its logo.
[[File:Penny hapenny.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Australian 1961 half penny and 1964 penny with Kangaroos.]]
==Kangaroos and coins== The kangaroo has been featured on pre-decimal coins, and on [[decimal]] coins.
The Kangaroo was featured on the Australian pre-decimal [[Coins of the Australian pound|penny]] coin.
The Kangaroo was also featured on the Australian pre-decimal [[Coins of the Australian pound|half-penny]] coin.
Five Kangaroos are featured on the Australian [[Coins of the Australian dollar|one dollar coin]]
==Kangaroo mascots in Australia== <!-- Commented out: [[File:Boxingkangaroo.svg|200px|thumb|Boxing Kangaroo flag, design used in 1983.]] -->
[[File:Opening ceremony (8075978683).jpg|thumb|''Matilda'', at the [[1982 Commonwealth Games]]]]
The ''[[Boxing kangaroo]]'' – mascot for the [[Australia II]] team in the 1983 [[America's Cup]]. This rendition of the kangaroo has become a sporting icon, known informally as the green and gold "Sporting Kangaroo", and is highly popular with cricket crowds and international sporting events which feature Australian participation.
''Matilda'', the [[mascot]] at the [[1982 Commonwealth Games]] held in [[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]], was represented by both a [https://web.archive.org/web/20070208150816/http://www.commonwealthgames.org.au/GamesInfo/PastGames/1982/Mascot.htm cartoon kangaroo] and a 13-metre high (42 feet 8 inches) mechanical kangaroo (which [[wink]]ed at the spectators during the opening and closing ceremonies). The 'medal', which was worn by both the cartoon and mechanical versions of ''Matilda'', features the [https://web.archive.org/web/20070208150729/http://www.commonwealthgames.org.au/GamesInfo/PastGames/1982/Logo.htm 1982 Commonwealth Games logo] — a [[Wiktionary:stylized|stylised]] representation of a kangaroo bounding (in "flight") – similar to the [[Wiktionary:pose|pose]] of the kangaroo featured on the pre-decimal half-penny coin.<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20070208150816/http://www.commonwealthgames.org.au/GamesInfo/PastGames/1982/Mascot.htm 1982 Commonwealth Games Mascot]," ''[[Australian Commonwealth Games Association]]''</ref>
During the [[World War I|First World War]], pet kangaroos and toy kangaroos were a popular choice of mascot for Australian servicemen.<ref>[http://cas.awm.gov.au/item/RELAWM07953 Kangaroo soft toy mascot: Red Cross Hut, Rouelles], [[Australian War Memorial]]</ref><ref>[https://www.flickr.com/photos/australian-war-memorial/3527160248/ Photograph: Australian nurse with a kangaroo mascot, Harefield, England], [[Australian War Memorial]]</ref>
[[File:Carlton club.jpg|thumb|200px|Kangaroo gargoyles atop The Carlton Club (built 1889) in [[Carlton, Victoria]].]]
==Architectural references== The first uses of Kangaroo ornaments as architectural expression appeared during the Victorian era. This was at first limited to the use of the coat of arms on buildings; however, kangaroos soon became used as decorative motifs on their own in some commercial buildings, particularly in [[Melbourne]].
It was the [[Federation architecture]], however, which brought native ornamentation into the mainstream, so that kangaroos began to be mass-produced as ornamentation on domestic houses in the large cities, as part of an Australiana movement and effort to create a uniquely Australian style. Examples of this decoration include the ornamental [[terracotta]] tile capping on residential roofs. Reproduction products using Kangaroos are still used today.
{{-}}
==Public art and sculpture== [[File:Perth Council House.jpg|thumb|Perth Council house kangaroo sculptures]] Kangaroo motifs have been used as a form of public art.
Notable examples include:
Victorian lamp post (1880) in front of the [[Royal Exhibition Building]] at the [[Carlton Gardens, Melbourne|Carlton Gardens]] in [[Carlton, Victoria]]
Petrie Tableaux sculpture (1989). In front of [[Brisbane City Hall]] at [[King George Square, Brisbane|King George Square]] by Stephen Walker
Perth kangaroo sculptures (1996, 1997 & 2000). [[St Georges Terrace, Perth|St Georges Terrace]], in several locations, [[Perth, Western Australia]], by Anne Neil, Joan Walsh-Smith, Charles Smith
City Roo sculptures (1999). [[George Street, Brisbane|George Street]], [[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]] - made from [[scrap]]metal by [[Christopher Trotter]]
Eastern grey kangaroo sculpture in the [[City Botanic Gardens]]
Kangaroo and joey sculpture at Queens Park in [[Ipswich, Queensland|Ipswich]], [[Queensland]]
{{-}}
<gallery> File:Melbourne Royal Exhibition - East Buildings.jpg|Kangaroo ornaments on a Victorian lamp post at the [[Royal Exhibition Building]] File:City_Hall_sculpture.jpg|Petrie Tableaux sculpture in front of [[Brisbane City Hall]] File:CityRoos_kangaroo_sculpture_1.jpg|One of the ''City Roo'' sculptures in George Street, Brisbane File:Kangaroo sculpture at Brisbane City Botanic Gardens.jpg|Eastern Grey kangaroo sculpture in the [[City Botanic Gardens]] File:Kangaroo-and-joey-sculpture_at_Queens_Park_in_Ipswich.jpg|Kangaroo and joey sculpture at Queens Park in [[Ipswich, Queensland|Ipswich]], Queensland </gallery>
==Decorative arts and design== An early depiction of a kangaroo on an item of [[Decorative arts|decorative art]] is the Macintosh & Degraves [[Token coin|Token]] Shilling 1823.<ref>[http://museumvictoria.com.au/collections/items/63320/token-1-shilling-macintosh-degraves-sawmills-hobart-tasmania-australia-1823 Macintosh & Degraves Token Shilling 1823], [[Museum Victoria]]</ref> Another early example is the Garret salver. This item of [[Tasmania]]n colonial silver incorporates a kangaroo, an emu and wattle branches in its design.<ref>[http://static.tmag.tas.gov.au/decorativeart/objects/metalware/P708/index.html Garrett salver], [[Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery]]</ref>
The kangaroo has continued to be incorporated into decorative designs by craftspeople and designers in Australia and elsewhere in the world. The Terence Lane kangaroo collection at the [[National Museum of Australia]] consists of more than 150 objects and ephemera in a wide range of styles produced over a period of 150 years. The collection ranges from a one-metre-high [[Royal Doulton|Doulton]] ceramic kangaroo umbrella stand to small items of jewellery.<ref>[http://www.nma.gov.au/collections/highlights/terence-lane-kangaroo-collection Terence Lane kangaroo collection], [[National Museum of Australia]]</ref>
==Cultural references== {{See also|List of fictional marsupials}} Kangaroos are extremely well represented in [[film]]s, [[television]], [[song]]s, [[toy]]s and [[souvenir]]s around the world.
===Television and films=== [[Skippy the Bush Kangaroo]], star of the 1960s Australian children's television series.
''[[Wake in Fright]]'' is a 1971 movie which includes a controversial kangaroo hunting scene containing graphic footage of kangaroos actually being shot.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wake in Fright - BBFC Insight|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/wake-fright-1971#bbfcinsight|website=British Board of Film Classification|accessdate=4 January 2015|date=28 January 2014}}</ref> In a more comic vein, the 1986 film ''[["Crocodile" Dundee]]'' features a scene in which the title character frightens away kangaroo hunters by making them think that a kangaroo is shooting back.<ref>{{cite book |last= Croft |first= David B. |title= Australian People and Animals in Today's Dreamtime: The Role of Comparative Psychology in the Management of Natural Resources |location= New York |publisher= Praeger |year= 1991 |page= 32 |ISBN= 0-275-93908-1 |quote= In Australia's latest version of the bush hero, Mick "Crocodile" Dundee, we find an explicitly totemic being who is a poacher turned conservationist as he chases away a group of kangaroo shooters at the behest of his American girlfriend.}}</ref>
''[[Matilda (1978 film)|Matilda]]'' is a 1978 movie starring [[Elliott Gould]] about a promoter working with a kangaroo.
[[Kangaroo Jack]] is the title character of an American film of the same name.
A giant kangaroo is featured in the movie ''[[Welcome to Woop Woop]].''
The Hallmark Properties television series ''[[Zoobilee Zoo]]'' has a character named Whazzat Kangaroo. (The Canadian actress and singer [[Stevie Vallance|Stephanie Louise "Stevie" Vallance]] acts out this role.)
===Songs=== Kangaroos are mentioned, or featured, in the [[Rolf Harris]] songs ''[[Tie Me Kangaroo Down, Sport]]'' and ''Six White Boomers''.
Kangaroos are also mentioned in the [[Peter Allen (musician)|Peter Allen]] song ''Tenterfield Saddler''.
Kangaroos are also mentioned in [[Holden]] jingle "Football, meat pies, kangaroos and Holden cars".
Kangaroos are also mentioned in the songs "Christmas Where The Gum Trees Grow", "Christmas in the Scrub" and "The Five Days of Christmas".
===Books=== There is a "Sour Kangaroo" in the Dr. Seuss tale ''[[Horton Hears A Who!]]''.
[[Kanga (Winnie-the-Pooh)|Kanga]] and [[Roo]] are [[fictional]] mother and son kangaroos in the popular series of children's books about [[Winnie-the-Pooh]].
Kidding Kangaroo in the ''[[Sweet Pickles]]'' book series by Ruth Lerner Perle, Jacquelyn Reinach and Richard Hefter.
One of the several intelligent races described in the fantasy novel ''[[Shadowkeep]],'' written by [[Alan Dean Foster]], are high-bounding, fun-loving marsupials, known as "roos" and obviously meant to be intelligent kangaroos.
A kangaroo is shot and [[Death|killed]] by [[Ernest]] in ''[[The Swiss Family Robinson]],'' a [[book]] written by [[Johann Wyss]].
===Cartoons=== [[Kiko the Kangaroo]] is a recurring character in ''[[Terrytoons]]'' cartoons.
[[Kanga (Winnie-the-Pooh)|Kanga]] and [[Roo]] are [[fictional]] mother and son kangaroos in the popular series of cartoons about [[Winnie-the-Pooh]].
A team of kangaroo [[basketball]] players feature in the [[France|French]] cartoon series ''[[Kangoo (cartoon)|Kangoo]]'' and its [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]]/[[prequel]] ''[[Kangoo Juniors]]''.
In several ''[[Looney Tunes]]''/''[[Merrie Melodies]]'' cartoons, [[Sylvester (Looney Tunes)|Sylvester the Cat]] is beaten up by [[Hippety Hopper]] the baby kangaroo, who always accomplishes this feat after escaping from the captivity of humans who have attempted to take him to a [[zoo]] in assorted American cities, and whom Sylvester believes to be an oversized [[mouse]].
In ''[[Tom and Jerry: The Fast and the Furry]]'', the commentators are holding a kangaroo by the leash when the racers reach [[Australia]].
In British punk style comic strips ''[[Tank Girl]]'', the protagonist's boyfriend is Booga, the mutant anthro kangaroo. There are some other minor roo characters. In the US movie [[Tank Girl]], slightly based on the strips, protagonist is assisted by Rippers - mutant Kangaroo genetically engineered supersoldiers (and Booga is among them, of course).
[[Rocko]] the wallaby in ''[[Rocko's Modern Life]]''
''[[Dot and the Kangaroo]]'' was a cartoon juxtaposed on film of the Australian bush.
In ''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[Bart vs. Australia]]", Homer and Bart try to escape from a crowd in the pouches of two kangaroos, which they ultimately can't because of the kangaroos' pouches being filled with mucus.
In ''[[Adventures of Sonic the Hedgehog]]'', there is a kangaroo named MacHopper, who is also a parody of [[Crocodile Dundee]], another Australian icon.
In the ''[[Kick Buttowski: Suburban Daredevil]]'' episode "Bwar and Peace", Brad talks about his Australian self, who after was punched, and the kangaroo appears before and during his wedding with the girl he's with. Kick also interacted with the kangaroo.
In the fifth season of ''[[The Flintstones]]'', the Rubbles adopt Hoppy, a pet hoparoo (a Stone Age version of a kangaroo) from Down Under, for Bamm-Bamm.
===Advertisements=== [[Aussie (shampoo)|Aussie]] hair products from [[Procter & Gamble]] sports a kangaroo hopping on its label, while the magazine and television ads display an animatronic purple kangaroo in them.
[[Dunkaroos]] are a snack in the USA which used to feature a talking kangaroo in commercials and product containers.
===Video games and other games=== Roo is a fighting kangaroo in the [[Sega Genesis]] video game ''[[Streets of Rage 3]]''.
[[List of Crash Bandicoot characters#Ripper Roo|Ripper Roo]], a crazy kangaroo in a straitjacket, is a boss character and antagonist of the video game series ''[[Crash Bandicoot]]''.
[[Kao the Kangaroo]] and its sequels are a Polish video game series involving an yellow/orange kangaroo in a boxing uniform as its protagonist.
Sheila, a female kangaroo of the video game series ''[[Spyro the Dragon (series)|Spyro the Dragon]]''.
[[Roger (Tekken)|Roger]] the boxing kangaroo from the ''[[Tekken (series)|Tekken]]'' series of video games.
In the Game Boy Color games ''[[The Legend of Zelda: Oracle of Seasons]]'' and ''[[The Legend of Zelda: Oracle of Ages]]'', there is a kangaroo by the name of Ricky which will help you in your quest.
In ''[[Mortal Kombat Trilogy]]'', [[Johnny Cage]] turns into a kangaroo.
In ''[[Bomberman]]'' 3 and 5 on [[SNES]], the animals which hatch from eggs are called rooeys and they are based on kangaroos.
The ''[[Animal Crossing]]'' series features kangaroos as possible neighbours.
There are at least three homonymous [[fairy chess pieces]] called kangaroo.
===Others=== Austin of ''[[The Backyardigans]]'' is a young kangaroo.
In [[Warriors of Virtue]], the five main heroes are roos.
In the [[Pokémon]] franchise, '' Kangaskhan'' is a Normal type based on a kangaroo with reptilian features. ''Breloom'', a Grass and Fighting type, is also partly based on a kangaroo with mushroom and boxing features.
In the anime and manga series [[Reborn!]] the character [[Ryohei Sasagawa]] has a kangaroo in one of his ring boxes that enables healing and advances abilities of others.
Chimera Punch, monster kangaroolike ''[[Tokyo Mew Mew]]''
==Kangaroos and sports teams== The kangaroo features prominently in sport. Australian sports teams with nicknames derived from the kangaroo (and [[wallaby]]) include the following:
===Australia===
====Australian national teams==== The [[Australian national rugby league team]] is nicknamed the ''Kangaroos''.
The [[Australia national rugby union team]] is nicknamed the ''Wallabies''.
The [[Australia national association football team]] (men's) is nicknamed the ''Socceroos''.
The [[Australia national under-23 football team]] plays [[Football at the Summer Olympics]] and is nicknamed ''Olyroos''.
The [[Australia national under-20 football team]] is nicknamed the ''Young Socceroos''
The [[Australia national under-17 football team]] is the ''Joeys''
The [[Hockeyroos|Australian Women's field hockey team]] is nicknamed the ''Hockeyroos''.
The [[Australian national ice hockey team]] is nicknamed the ''Mighty Roos''.
The [[Australia men's national basketball team|Australian men's national basketball team]] is nicknamed the ''Boomers''.
====Australian domestic teams==== The [[North Melbourne Football Club]] in the [[Australian Football League]] is nicknamed the ''Kangaroos''.
[[Perth Kangaroos IFC]]
===United States=== ''Kasey Kangaroo'' is the mascot for the [[University of Missouri–Kansas City]]
''Zippy'' the kangaroo is the mascot for [[University of Akron|The University of Akron]]
The kangaroo is the mascot for [[Austin College]] in [[Sherman, Texas]]
The kangaroo is the mascot for [[Terryville High School]] in [[Terryville, Connecticut]]
''Lizzie'' (a purple and white kangaroo) is the mascot of [[Lake Washington High School]] in [[Kirkland, Washington]]
''Stomper'' is the mascot for the [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]] wrestling company.
The kangaroo is the mascot for [[State University of New York at Canton]] in [[Canton (town), New York]]
The kangaroo is the mascot for [[Wilmington Friends School]] in [[Wilmington, Delaware]]
''Moe the Kangaroo'' is the mascot for [[Virginia Military Institute]] in [[Lexington, Virginia]]
[[Nashville Kangaroos]]
The kangaroo is the mascot for [[Killeen High School]] in [[Killeen, Texas]].
Weatherford, Texas High School's mascot is the Kangaroos
[[Abington Friends School]], in [[Abington Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Abington, Pennsylvania]], has a kangaroo named Roo as its mascot.
===Other countries=== The [[Samoa national Australian rules football team]] is nicknamed the ''Kangaroos''.
The [[Bohemians 1905|FC Bohemians Praha]], a [[Czech Republic|Czech]] [[association football|football]] team is nicknamed the ''Klokani'' ([[Czech language|Czech]] for kangaroos) since their tour in [[Australia]] in 1927.
[[Etobicoke Kangaroos]]
[[Vienna Kangaroos]]
==Place names== The kangaroo has inspired a number of place names in Australia. They include:
[[New South Wales]] * [[Kangaroo Point, New South Wales|Kangaroo Point]] * [[Brooklyn, New South Wales#Kangaroo Point|Kangaroo Point]] - (Brooklyn) * [[Kangaroo River (Clarence Valley)|Kangaroo River]] - (Clarence Valley) * [[Kangaroo River (Shoalhaven)|Kangaroo River]] - (Shoalhaven) * [[Kangaroo Valley, New South Wales|Kangaroo Valley]]
[[Queensland]] * [[Kangaroo Island (Queensland)|Kangaroo Island]] * [[Kangaroo Point, Queensland|Kangaroo Point]] * [[Kangaroo Point Cliffs]] * [[Kangaroo River (Queensland)|Kangaroo River]]
[[South Australia]] * [[Kangaroo Creek Reservoir]] * [[Kangaroo Flat, South Australia|Kangaroo Flat]] *[[Kangaroo Island]]
[[Tasmania]] *[[East Kangaroo Island]] *[[Kangaroo Island (Tasmania)|Kangaroo Island]]
[[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] * [[Kangaroo Flat, Victoria|Kangaroo Flat]] * [[Kangaroo Ground, Victoria|Kangaroo Ground]]
[[Western Australia]] *[[Kangaroo Island (Shark Bay)|Kangaroo Island]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{Heraldic creatures}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Kyoto Nishikyogoku Athletic Stadium | nick_name = | fullname = Kyoto Nishikyogoku Athletic Stadium | image = [[File:Nishikyogoku stadium20130428.JPG|250px]] | publictransit = '''[[Hankyu Railway]]''':
[[File:Number prefix Hankyu Kyoto line.png|15px]] [[Hankyu Kyoto Main Line|Kyoto Main Line]] at {{STN|Nishikyogoku}} | location = {{flagicon|Japan}} [[Kyoto]], [[Japan]] | coordinates = {{coord|34|59|36.52|N|135|42|50.26|E|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1942 | renovated = | expanded = 1985, 1996 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Kyoto City | operator = | surface = Grass | Constructor = | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | nicknames = | tenants = [[Kyoto Sanga FC]] | seating_capacity = 20,588 | dimensions = 125 m × 78 m }} {{nihongo|'''Kyoto Nishikyogoku Athletic Stadium'''|京都市西京極総合運動公園陸上競技場兼球技場|Kyōtō-shi Nishikyōgoku Sōgō Undō Kōen Rikujō-kyōgijō ken Kyūgijō}} is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Ukyo-ku, Kyoto|Ukyo-ku]], [[Kyoto]], [[Japan]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[J.League]] club [[Kyoto Sanga FC]] The stadium holds 20,588 people and was built in 1942. It hosted the [[Football at the 1964 Summer Olympics|football]] match between [[Romania at the 1964 Summer Olympics|Romania]] and [[Ghana at the 1964 Summer Olympics|Ghana]] during the [[1964 Summer Olympics]]. == Access == 3-minute walk from [[Nishi-Kyōgoku Station]] on the [[Hankyū Kyoto Main Line]]. == Events == * [[Kyoto Marathon]] * [[All-Japan High School Ekiden Championship]] * [[Inter-Prefectural Women's Ekiden]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{commons category}} *[https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=512/edition=197085/matches/match=32088/report.html FIFA.com 1964 Summer Olympics ROU-GHA results.] – accessed 14 August 2010. {{en icon}} * [http://kanko.city.kyoto.lg.jp/detail.php?InforKindCode=1&ManageCode=9000006 Facilities Guide], Kyoto City Office {{ja icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130502140351/http://www.kyoto-sports.or.jp/accessmap/index.html Stadium Information], Kyoto City Amateur Sports Association {{ja icon}} {{Kyoto Sanga F.C.}} {{J. revision.text:
{{coord|36.8818|-76.3135|type:landmark_region:US-VA|display=title}} The '''L.R. Hill Sports Complex''' is an athletic building on the campus of [[Old Dominion University]] in [[Norfolk, Virginia]]. Construction started in August 2007 and the building opened on September 13, 2008. Built by S.B. Ballard, who has constructed many buildings at ODU including the [[Ted Constant Center]] and the University Village Apartments.<ref>http://hamptonroads.com/2009/07/little-extra-story A little extra to the story </ref>
==Description== The L.R. Hill Sports Complex is a {{convert|48000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} building that houses Old Dominion Football, Women's Lacrosse, and Women's Field Hockey. The facility cost $17 Million to build.<ref> http://hamptonroads.com/node/305111. Ground broken on ODU's $17 million Powhatan Sports Center </ref> It is located along Powhatan Avenue near the Lambert's Point Golf Club and Golf Course. Included in the Powhatan Sports Complex is a {{convert|6000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} area for strength & conditioning, players lounges, locker rooms, high definition screens, and a {{convert|3000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} athletic training area.<ref>http://www.odusports.com/ot/oldd-08-powhatan-sports-complex.html Powhatan Sports Complex </ref>
==History== Motivation for the complex began with the re-addition of [[American football|football]] to Old Dominion University. The school used to have a team from 1930–41 and in 2005 the Board of Visitors voted unanimously in favor of adding football.
To get land for the complex, just less than 3 acres, ODU gave the city of Norfolk 3 acres of land near Lambert's Point across Hampton Boulevard.<ref>https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/dailypress/access/1046203731.html?dids=1046203731:1046203731&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+01%2C+2006&author=MICHAEL+C.+WRIGHT+mwright2@dailypress.com+%7C+247-4759&pub=Daily+Press&desc=ODU+IS+READY+FOR+FOOTBALL%2C+AGAIN&pqatl=google ODU Ready for Football, Again </ref>
For [[lacrosse]] and [[field hockey]], a new field was built that shares the both. Stands face east, with the press box on the opposite side. Their offices are located on the 1st and 2nd floors of the complex. All three occupants share the athletic and strength & conditioning areas, while individually having their own offices and locker rooms.
==Football== The football offices are located on the 2nd floor of the building. Coaches offices and meeting rooms occupy the upstairs. The players' locker rooms, lounge and equipment room are located on the 1st floor near the practice fields. A 100-yard football field and a 60-yard football field was built adjacent to the lacrosse and field hockey stadium. All outside areas are equipped with lighting for night practice and/or games.
The grass used for the football practice fields are GameDay Grass 3D and were supplied by GeneralSports Venue (GSV). GameDay Grass 3D is a form of astroturf. GameDay is also used by the [[Buffalo Bills]], [[Toronto Blue Jays]], and [[Tampa Bay Rays]].<ref>http://www.astroturfusa.com/GameDay-Grass.aspx Astroturf Gameday Grass </ref>
==NCAA Field Hockey Final Four== The Powhatan Sports Complex has received national attention and has hosted the 2012, 2013 and 2016 NCAA Field Hockey Final Four. This will be the fourth time the event will on the campus of Old Dominion University, with previous events being held at Foreman Field in 1985, 1986, and 2000.<ref>http://hamptonroads.com/2010/06/odu-host-field-hockey-final-four-2012-and-2013 ODU to host field hockey Final Four in 2012 and 2013 </ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Old Dominion University}} {{Old Dominion Monarchs football navbox}}

page.title: List of retired numbers in association football

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{multiple issues| {{original research|date=February 2012}} {{refimprove|date=February 2012}} }} [[Association football]] clubs around the world sometimes retire [[squad number]]s to recognise players' loyal service, sometimes as a memorial after their death.
==Background== This practice, long established in the [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|major North American sports]], is a recent development in football since squad numbers for specific players were not widely used until the 1990s. Before then, it was typical for players in the starting lineup to be issued numbers 1 to 11 by formation/position on a match-by-match basis, and substitutes to be numbered from 12 upwards, meaning a player might wear different numbers during the season if they were to play in different positions for tactical reasons, or simply not be a regular in the starting lineup.
Retiring a player's number usually occurs after the player has left the team or retired. It honours a player who has meant so much to his club that they retire the shirt number that the player wore during their time there, meaning no other player is permitted to use that number in the future. In some cases, such as those of [[Jason Mayélé]], [[Vittorio Mero]], [[Marc-Vivien Foé]], [[Miklós Fehér]], [[Ray Jones (footballer born 1988)|Ray Jones]], [[Dylan Tombides]], [[François Sterchele]], [[David di Tommaso]], [[Antonio Puerta]], [[Besian Idrizaj]], [[Piermario Morosini]] and [[Davide Astori]], numbers have been retired to posthumously honour a player who died while still active. Also, Norwegian club [[Fredrikstad F.K.|Fredrikstad]] retired [[Dagfinn Enerly]]'s number following an on-pitch accident that left him [[paraplegia|paralysed]]. In Britain, only [[Bobby Moore]]'s and [[Jack Lester]]'s shirt numbers have been retired due to great service to the club as opposed to a tragic incident. Although it has not been officially retired, [[Gianfranco Zola|Gianfranco Zola's]] No. 25 shirt has not been reissued by Chelsea since he left the club in 2003.
The [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]], [[Ecuador national football team|Ecuador]] and [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]] national teams have been prevented from retiring the numbers of [[Diego Maradona]] (10), [[Christian Benítez]] (11)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/03/06/soccer-friendlies-latam-idUKL3N0M33JT20140306|title=Soccer-Ecuador to reinstate Benitez's number 11 for World Cup|date=6 March 2014|publisher=reuters.com}}</ref> and [[Marc-Vivien Foé]] (17), respectively, by [[FIFA]] rules dealing with squad numbers for Finals tournaments; in other competitions or [[Friendly match|friendlies]], national associations may assign numbers according to criteria of their choosing. Similarly, several clubs have been required to reissue retired numbers for continental club competitions due to squad numbering rules of continental confederations. For example, [[Confederation of African Football|CAF]] and [[CONMEBOL]] have such rules in their club competitions, but [[CONCACAF]] does not.
Some South American teams (such as [[Universitario de Deportes]] or [[Flamengo]], and even Mexican teams invited for the occasions) have occasionally had to re-issue their retired numbers for special cases due to CONMEBOL rules, which state that shirts must be numbered 1–25 in continental club competitions (such as [[Copa Libertadores]] and [[Copa Sudamericana]], among others).

==Special cases== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! width=170px | Team ! width=40px | No. ! width=150px | Player ! width=100px | Pos. ! width=100px | Career ! width=150px | Notes |- | {{flagicon|Italy}} [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] | 3 | {{flagicon|Italy}} [[Paolo Maldini]] | [[Defender (association football)#Left-back|Left back]], [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|Centre-back]] | 1984–2009 | The shirt was not fully retired. Maldini has given consent for his sons to adopt the number 3 shirt if either of them play professionally for the club.<ref name = "Guardian"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Maldini shirt waits for 3G |url=http://www.channel4.com/sport/football_italia/may25p.html |publisher=Channel 4 |date=26 May 2007 |accessdate=2007-05-26 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070527120524/http://www.channel4.com/sport/football_italia/may25p.html |archivedate=27 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> |- | {{flagicon|ITA}} [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] | 6 | {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Aldair]] | [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|Centre-back]] | 1990–2003 | The shirt number had been retired by the club when the player left the club in 2003. When [[Kevin Strootman]] joined Roma in 2013, he asked for permission to wear number 6. The club approved the request after Aldair gave his consent.<ref>[http://www.asroma.com/en/news/2015/11/aldair-at-50-13-facts-you-need-to-know Aldair at 50: 13 facts you need to know]</ref> |- | {{flagicon|CZE}} [[SK Slavia Praha|Slavia]] | 7 | {{flagicon|CZE}} [[Stanislav Vlček]] | [[Forward_(association_football)#Striker|Striker]] | 2004-2007, 2009-2013 | Rather than retiring the number, the club opted to freeze the number for any future player that wants it, provided that the applying player meets 7 game achievements. Among those are scoring 3 goals overall against [[AC Sparta Praha|Sparta]], being nominated for his national team, winning the trophy for top goalscorer and others. Even though [[Milan Škoda]] met the requirements in [[2016–17 Czech First League|2016-17 season]], he opted to keep his number 21. The 7 was eventually given to [[Danny (footballer)|Danny]] upon him joining the team for [[2017–18 Czech First League|2017-18 season]]. Vlček gave his consent and Danny pledged to work to meet the remaining criteria.<ref>[http://slavia.cz/clanek.asp?id=Danny-bude-nosit-cislo-7-Velka-zodpovednost-hlasi-14793]</ref> |- | {{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] | 10 | {{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Diego Maradona]] | [[midfielder (football)|Midfielder]] | 1979–1994 | The number 10 had been retired by [[Argentine Football Association]] in October 2001 to honour Maradona. Before the [[2002 FIFA World Cup|2002 World Cup]], the AFA submitted a squad list of 23 players for the tournament, listed 1 through 24, with the number 10 omitted.<ref name = "Guardian"/> FIFA rejected Argentina's list, and the governing body's president, [[Sepp Blatter]] suggested the number 10 shirt be instead given to the team's third-choice goalkeeper, [[Roberto Bonano]]. AFA ultimately submitted a revised list with [[Ariel Ortega]], originally listed as number 23, as the number 10.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/worldcup2002/hi/team_pages/argentina/newsid_2010000/2010680.stm |title=Ortega fills Maradona's shirt |date=27 May 2002 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> The number 10 has been worn by other players since, most notably by [[Lionel Messi]], whom Maradona considers his "successor." |- | {{flagicon|Scotland}} [[Dunfermline Athletic F.C.|Dunfermline Athletic]] | 4 | {{flagicon|Scotland}} [[Norrie McCathie]] | [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] | 1981–1996 | The club retired the number after club captain McCathie was found dead in his home on 8 January 1996, as a result of [[Carbon Monoxide]] poisoning.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nmbf.org.uk/profile.php |title=NMBF Profile |accessdate=2007-01-26 |work=Norrie McCathie Benevolent Fund |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929070314/http://www.nmbf.org.uk/profile.php |archivedate=29 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> At that time, Scottish League clubs used shirt numbered from 1 to 11, so for the remainder of the 1995–96 season, 12 was used instead. However, the number was not retired permanently, and has been re-issued since. |- | {{flagicon|ITA}} [[AS Livorno Calcio|Livorno]] | 10 | {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Igor Protti]] | [[Striker (football)|Striker]] | 1985–1988, 1999–2005 | In December 2005, Livorno officially retired the #10 jersey. However, Protti, who led the forward line and captained his side in two promotions from Serie C1 to Serie A, quickly gaining a reputation as a fan favourite, announced his willingness to see the #10 number reissued to another player, in order to "give anybody back a dream to dress it one day." This was made effective starting from the [[Serie A 2007–08|2007–08 season]], in which [[Francesco Tavano]] played with the #10 number.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/SerieA/Squadre/Livorno/Primo_Piano/2007/07_Luglio/20/10_tavano.shtml|publisher=Gazzetta dello Sport|title=Protti rimanda in campo il 10. A Livorno lo avrà Tavano|language=Italian|date=20 July 2007|accessdate=20 July 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070822152600/http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/SerieA/Squadre/Livorno/Primo_Piano/2007/07_Luglio/20/10_tavano.shtml| archivedate= 22 August 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> |- | {{flagicon|England}} [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] | 9 | {{flagicon|England}} [[Adam Stansfield]] | [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | 2006–2010 | The club retired the number 9 for nine seasons after the striker died of cancer on 10 August 2010.<ref name="Club Retires Number 9 Shirt"/> |- | {{flagicon|Israel}} [[Maccabi Tel Aviv FC|Maccabi Tel-Aviv]] | 12 | {{flagicon|Israel}} [[Meni Levi]] | [[Defender (football)|Defender]] | –2007 | During a game between [[Maccabi Tel Aviv FC|Maccabi Tel-Aviv]] and [[Beitar Jerusalem FC|Beitar Jerusalem]], Levi chest-controlled and kicked the ball, ran back to defend, then collapsed. He returned to his feet, and then collapsed a second time. He was subsequently on a life-support machine, and has since returned home. The club claims that the number 12 is unofficially reserved for the fans.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eternal-allegiance.com/f14/levi-continue-rehabilitation-home-39993/ |title=Levi continues rehab at home |accessdate=2007-01-26 |work=Eternal-Allegiance |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65ttkmWk5?url=http://www.eternal-allegiance.com/ |archivedate=4 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- | {{flagicon|Peru}} [[Universitario de Deportes|Universitario]] || 9 || {{flagicon|Peru}} [[Teodoro Fernández|Lolo Fernández]] || [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] || 1930–53 || Number retired only for the 2013 season.<ref>[http://www.larepublica.pe/14-01-2013/universitario-de-deportes-retira-dorsal-9-por-centenario-del-lolo-fernandez "Universitario de Deportes retira dorsal '9' por centenario del Lolo Fernández", on ''La República'', 14 January 2013]</ref> |- | {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] | 17 | {{flagicon|Italy}} [[Massimo Cellino]] | Chairman | 2014 | Leeds retired the number 17 shirt due to Italian chairman Massimo Cellino's superstitions, as 17 is considered an unlucky number in [[Culture of Italy|Italian culture]]. |- | {{flagicon|Scotland}} [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]] | 10 | {{flagicon|Scotland}} [[Phil O'Donnell (footballer)|Phil O'Donnell]] | [[Midfielder]] | 1990–1994, 2004–2007 | Phil O'Donnell collapsed while playing for Motherwell against [[Dundee United FC|Dundee United]] in 2007. He was later pronounced dead at Wishaw General Hospital. The number 10 shirt was worn by his nephew [[David Clarkson]] during the 2008-09 season. Since Clarkson left in June 2009, it has not been retired, but has not been issued to any subsequent player. |- | {{flagicon|South Africa}} [[Orlando Pirates Football Club|Orlando Pirates]] | 22 | {{flagicon|South Africa}} [[Lesley Manyathela]] | [[Striker (association football)|Striker]] | 2000−2003 | The club retired the number 22, after Manyathela died in a car crash in August, 2003. However, [[Confederation of African Football]] rules state that shirts must be numbered 1–30 in continental club competitions, so Pirates has been re-issued it in those special cases. |- | {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Real Oviedo]] | 10 | {{flagicon|Slovakia}} [[Peter Dubovský (footballer)|Peter Dubovsky]] | [[Midfielder]] | 1995–2000 | The [[Liga de Fútbol Profesional|Spanish Football League]] allowed Oviedo to retire number 10 just for the 2000–2001 season, as an exception to its rules. At the end of the season, number 10 was re-issued. |- | {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] | 16 | {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Antonio Puerta]] | [[Left back]], [[Winger (sports)|Left winger]] | 2004–2007 | The shirt has not been fully retired. It was temporarily retired after Puerta died of a cardiac arrest on the first matchday in La Liga 2007–2008 However, the Spanish Football Federation rules state that clubs must use number 1 to 25 for their regular squad, and as a result, [[David Prieto]] wore the number in 2008 in honour of his friend.<ref>{{cite news |title=Prieto: Wearing Puerta's No. 16 Is An Honour|url=http://www.goal.com/en-india/Articolo.aspx?ContenutoId=790559 |publisher=Goal.com|date=25 July 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-07 }}</ref> |- | {{flagicon|Norway}} [[Stabæk Fotball|Stabæk]] | 7 | {{flagicon|Norway}} [[Christer Basma]] | [[Defender (football)#Centre-back|Central defender]] | 1995–1998 | The club had retired the number to honor his services for the club. However, the retirement was revoked after 2004 season and the number given to [[Henning Hauger]]. |- | {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | 25 | {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Gianfranco Zola]] | [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | 1996–2003 | Chelsea have not officially retired the number 25 shirt, but it has not been allocated to another player since Zola left the club in 2003. |- | {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] | 13 | {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Aaron Flahavan]] | [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | 1994–2001 | Following Flahavan's death in a car accident in August 2001, Portsmouth and his first club, [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], retired their number 1 shirts for the 2001-02 season as a mark of respect. From the 2003-04 season, Portsmouth retired the number 13 shirt, as this was the number Flahavan wore during the majority of his time at the club. Number 13 remained unused until 2011, when it was allocated to goalkeeper [[Stephen Henderson (footballer born 1988)|Stephen Henderson]], and it has been reissued since. |- | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Los Angeles Galaxy|LA Galaxy]] || 13 || {{flagicon|USA}} [[Cobi Jones]] || || 1996–2007 || The number was not officially retired by the Galaxy but had not been worn since Jones retired. In 2017, it was given to [[Jermaine Jones]].<ref>[https://www.lagalaxy.com/post/2017/02/07/cobi-jones-confirms-jermaine-jones-will-wear-la-galaxy-no-13-kit-insider Cobi Jones confirms that Jermaine Jones will wear the LA Galaxy No. 13 kit] by Adam Serrano on LA Galaxy website, 7 Feb 2017</ref> |- | {{flagicon|FIN}} [[FC Haka]] | 14 | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Valeri Popovitch]] | [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | 1994–2008 | First ever retired shirt number in the history of Finnish football is ex-Haka's Valeri Popovitch's number 14. Popovitch has stated that his sons, who are still playing for Haka's junior teams, can wear the legendary number if they want.<ref>{{cite news |title=Numero 14 poistui käytöstä |url=http://www.fchaka.fi/etusivu/542-numero-14-poistui-kaeytoestae |publisher=fchaka.fi |date=13 July 2009 |accessdate=2009-07-14 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120729170254/http://www.fchaka.fi/etusivu/542-numero-14-poistui-kaeytoestae |archive-date=29 July 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- | {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]] | 14 | {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Mark Philo]] | [[Midfielder]] | 2004–2006 | Philo was killed in a car accident and the number 14 shirt retired. It was later revealed he was significantly over the drink-drive limit and his car veered on to the other side of the road, killing a 58-year-old mother of two.<ref>http://www.thisislocallondon.co.uk/news/772566.football_star_had_7_pints_before_fatal_crash/</ref> |- | {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] | 16 | {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Luc Borrelli]] | [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | 1998–1999 | posthumous — returned to use in 2011 |- | {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] | 17 | {{flagicon|CMR}} [[Marc-Vivien Foé]] | [[Midfielder]] | 2000–2003 | posthumous — returned to use in 2008 |- | {{flagicon|GER}} [[1. FC Köln]] | 10 | {{flagicon|GER}} [[Lukas Podolski]] | [[Winger (sports)|Winger]] | 2002–06, 2009–12 | The club had announced that the number would remain out of circulation as long as Podolski is playing football on a professional level. Nevertheless, the #10 was given to [[Patrick Helmes]] in July 2014.<ref>[http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/3275/bundesliga/2014/07/06/4940029/podolski-vexed-as-koln-u-turn-on-promise-to-retire-his-shirt "Podolski vexed as Koln U-turn on promise to retire his shirt", Goal.com, 6 July 2014]</ref> |- | {{flagicon|TUR}} [[Galatasaray S.K. (football)|Galatasaray]] | 3 | {{flagicon|TUR}} [[Bülent Korkmaz]] | [[Central defender]] | 1984–2005 | Despite the club announcing the retirement of the number, it has been re-issued. |- | {{flagicon|COL}} [[Independiente Santa Fe]] | 23 | {{flagicon|COL}} [[Léider Preciado]] | [[Striker (association football)|Striker]] | 1995–1998, 2000–2001, 2004–2005, 2006–2008, 2011 | The number was out of circulation for a period of 23 months (starting May 2012) in honor of the second top scorer in the history of the club.<ref>[http://sangrecardenal.net/2012/05/adios-a-la-23/ "Adiós a la 23", Sangre Cardenal, May 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20140711190823/http://sangrecardenal.net/2012/05/adios-a-la-23/ |date=11 July 2014 }}</ref> |- | {{flagicon|MEX}} [[C.D. Guadalajara]] | 11 | {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Ramón Morales]] | [[Midfielder]] | 1998–2011, 2013– (as part of the coaching staff). | The shirt was never officially retired, but it was not issued out of American competitions for the time between Morales' exit and his return as a coach. All players intending to wear the jersey have to ask for Morales' consent. It is now being worn by [[Aldo de Nigris|Jesús Aldo De Nigris]] since he has received Morales' approval.<ref>[http://www.goal.com/es-mx/news/4774/liga-bancomer-mx/2013/06/09/4037601/aldo-de-nigris-solicita-permiso-a-ramón-morales-para-portar "Aldo de Nigris solicita permiso a Ramón Morales para portar el '11'", Goal.com]</ref> |- | {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Club de Fútbol Pachuca|Pachuca]] | 8 | {{Flagicon|Mexico}} [[Gabriel Caballero]] | [[Midfielder]]/[[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | 1998–2002, 2003–2004, 2005–2009 | His number was just temporaly retired for 5 years. After that period, it was reactivated and given to [[Hirving Lozano]] in 2014.<ref>[http://www.espn.com.ar/news/nota/_/id/2137455/caballero-regreso-el-retirado-numero-8-a-pachuca-para-hirving-lozano Caballero regresó el retirado número 8 a Pachuca para Hirving Lozano], ESPN</ref> |- | {{flagicon|JPN}} [[Sagan Tosu]] | 17 | {{flagicon|JPN}} [[Sakata Michitaka]] | Non-player | 2001– | The shirt was retired posthumously, to honour Michikata who played a key role in establishment of former [[Tosu Futures]] and their revival as Sagan Tosu, and who died due to kidney cancer on 7 January 2000. Number 17, derived from the day of his death, was selected to be retired. The number would later also be dedicated to the club's fans, thus they have not retired squad number 12 like most Japanese League teams. |- | {{flagicon|ESP}} [[FC Barcelona]] | 21 | {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Luis Enrique (footballer)|Luis Enrique]] | [[Midfielder]] | 1996–2004 | Joined the club as a free agent from eternal rivals [[Real Madrid]], and spent eight years at FC Barcelona. In his last years, he became the captain of the team. The shirt was retired for just two years (2004–06), since [[La Liga]] did not allow to retire numbers permanently. Former coach of the team. The number 21 shirt was awarded to [[Lilian Thuram]] in 2006. |- | {{flagicon|GER}} [[Schalke 04]] | 7 | {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Raúl (footballer)|Raúl]] | [[Striker (association football)|Striker]] | 2010–2012 | At the time Raúl left the club, the team intended to retire the jersey indefinitely.<ref>{{cite news |title=Auf Wiedersehen, Raul! Schalke's Spanish superstar leaves behind a legendary legacy in Germany|url=http://www.goal.com/en-my/news/4004/germany/2012/04/19/3046693/auf-wiedersehen-raul-schalkes-spanish-superstar-leaves?ICID=AR_RA_1 |publisher=Goal.com|date=19 April 2012 |accessdate=2015-03-28 }}</ref> However, the retirement of this shirt only lasted one year; since 2013 it has been worn by [[Max Meyer (footballer)|Max Meyer]]. |- |}
==Dedication to fans== {{Refimprove section|date=July 2015}} Some clubs dedicate a number to their fans, and do not issue it to any player. The most common number for this practice is 12, from descriptions of the fans as "[[12th man (football)|the twelfth man]]".
In Japanese footballing tradition, almost all the professional teams retired the number 12 for their supporters. The only two teams not to retire 12 are [[Urawa Red Diamonds]] and [[Sagan Tosu]] (Sagan retired 17 for a similar reason).

'''Notes''': <sup>1</sup> Despite of having their number "12" retired, Brazilian clubs have had to re-issue them for [[CONMEBOL]] competitions such as [[Copa Libertadores]], where rosters must be numbered from 1 to 25 consecutively.<ref>[http://www.conmebol.com/export/sites/conmebol/Docs/Copa_Libertadores/2012/Lista-jugadores_Libertadores-2012.pdf "Lista de Jugadores Copa Libertadores 2012" (Flamengo roster included) - CONMEBOL] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324044843/http://www.conmebol.com/export/sites/conmebol/Docs/Copa_Libertadores/2012/Lista-jugadores_Libertadores-2012.pdf |date=24 March 2012 }}</ref>
<sup>2</sup> Exeter City reserve the number 12 shirt for the 'Twelfth Man' sponsor of individual games. <ref>[http://www.exetercityfc.co.uk/documents/exeter-city-corporate-brochure-2014-15125-1549858.pdf "Exeter City Hospitality Brochure 2014/15"]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Peterborough United]] retired the number 12 as a dedication to the posh12's the fans
[[AIK Fotboll|AIK]] and [[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgården IF]] reserve the number 1 for their supporters.
[[Indy Eleven]] reserve the number 11 for their supporters.
[[Reading F.C.|Reading]], [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] and [[Bryne FK|Bryne]] reserve the number 13 for their supporters, [[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]] reserve this number in honour of [[Gate 13]], the [[ultras]] based in the respective gate in home matches. [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] also reserve the number 13 shirt for "the fans" while [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] reserve the number 13 shirt for the fan who wins a pre-season competition.
After their 15-point deduction, [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] retired the number 15 shirt for the [[Leeds United A.F.C. season 2007-08|2007–08 season]] only.<ref>{{cite web|title=Squad Numbers |url=http://www.leedsunited.com/page/NewsroomDetail/0,,10273~1355522,00.html |work=LeedsUnited.com |accessdate=1 Aug 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080805040225/http://www.leedsunited.com/page/NewsroomDetail/0%2C%2C10273~1355522%2C00.html |archivedate=5 August 2008 |df= }}</ref>
[[Bursaspor]] reserve the number 16 for their supporters.
[[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] use squad number 27 for the Steve Fletcher Stand which houses the large majority of hardcore supporters, the number 50 for "12th man" and the number 99 shirt for their mascot, Cherry Bear.
[[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] use squad number 13 for the 'Rainham End' Stand of Priestfield Stadium as this stand holds the majority of hardcore supporters.
[[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] reserve the number 40 for their fans.
[[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]] have reserved the number 13 in honor of [[Gate 13]].
[[Levadiakos F.C.|Levadiakos]] have reserved the number 10 for the club president, Giannis Kobotis.
[[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] have reserved the number 50 for the mascot, Filbert Fox, which he wears on his shirt at every game.
[[APOEL FC|APOEL]] have reserved the shirt number 79 in honour of [[APOEL FC#Supporters|PAN.SY.FI.]] (APOEL [[Ultras]]), to denote the year the group was founded, 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sentragoal.philenews.com/article.asp?catid=19171&subid=2&pubid=72090657|title=To "79" ανήκει στους πορτοκαλί!|language=Greek|publisher=sentragoal.philenews.com|date=12 October 2010|accessdate=2 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808045018/http://sentragoal.philenews.com/article.asp?catid=19171&subid=2&pubid=72090657|archivedate=8 August 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] retired the number 55 shirt on 13 January 2017 in honour of five-year old Joshua McCormack who lost his battle with cancer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rochdaleafc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/rochdale-football-club-saddened-to-learn-of-the-passing-of-joshua-mccormack-3517135.aspx}}</ref>
[[Atlanta United]] reserve the number 17 for their supporters and to reference their [[2017 Atlanta United FC season|inaugural season]] in [[Major League Soccer]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rossitch|first1=Eric|title=Atlanta, Number 17 is for You|url=http://www.atlutd.com/post/2017/02/10/atlanta-number-17-you|website=Atlanta United FC|date=February 10, 2017|accessdate=August 25, 2018}}</ref>

{{Chinese name|[[Mai (surname)|Mak]]}} {{Infobox racing driver | name = Mak Ka Lok | image = | imagesize = | caption = | nationality = {{flagicon|MAC}} Macau | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|08|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Hong Kong]] | current series = [[World Touring Car Championship]] | first year = [[2011 World Touring Car Championship season|2011]] | current team = [[RPM Racing|RPM Racing Team]] | car number = 44 | former teams = | starts = 14 | wins = 0 | poles = 0 | fastest laps = 0 | best finish = NC | year = [[2011 World Touring Car Championship season|2011]]-[[2014 World Touring Car Championship season|2014]] | prev series = | prev series years = | titles = | title years = | awards = | award years = }} '''Mak Ka Lok''' ({{lang|zh|麥家樂}};{{cite news|url=http://www.mastvnet.com/news/macau/entertainment/2015-11-20/news_content_65740.shtml|script-title=zh:明星蓮花挑戰賽 澳門車手麥家樂獲排頭位|publisher=MAS TV|date=20 November 2015|access-date=22 August 2017}} born 17 August 1965) is a Macanese race car driver. Mak has raced in Touring Car Championships within Asia and drove the final two rounds of the [[2011 World Touring Car Championship season|2011 World Touring Car Championship]] in a [[BMW 3 Series (E90)|BMW 320si]]http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/02112011/58/mak-ka-lok-race-macau.html Eurosport.com, retrieved 6 November 2011.
